text.content: The Role of Early Childhood Professionals
Learning to communicate through the use of language is one of the most important aspects of a child’s cognitive, social, and emotional development.

Many parents encourage their children's language development by talking, singing, and reading with them. However, parents may not realize how critical their role is in promoting their children’s verbal skills and abilities.

Early childhood professionals can help educate parents on the importance of early verbal development by:
  • Understanding the ways young children learn language
  • Discussing the importance of a language-rich environment
  • Reinforcing basic communication needs of children

Key Message:

  • Parents and caregivers have a unique role in fostering a child’s early linguistic development because language development is essentially a social behavior.

audio.transcript: Learning to communicate through the use of language is one of the most important aspects of a child's cognitive, social, and emotional development. Language gives children the tools they need to make sense of their world and to communicate their own thoughts, ideas, and feelings.

Many parents encourage their children's language development by talking, singing, and reading with them. However, parents may not realize how critical their role is in promoting their children's verbal skills and abilities. As trusted childhood advocates, early childhood professionals can help parents understand how a child learns to use language to communicate and how they can best support their child’s language acquisition.

Early childhood professionals can help educate parents on the importance of early verbal development by: Understanding the ways that young children learn language, discussing with parents the importance of a language-rich environment and helping parents and caregivers reinforce the basic communication needs of children.
The Key Message of this section is that parents and caregivers have a unique role in fostering a child’s early linguistic development because language development is essentially a social behavior.
